ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good survey of empirical research in a wide array of fields in cognitive science
I learned about different research going on in the broad field of CogSci as well as how to start planning for senior thesis.
Learned about multiple different disciplines in the field of cognitive science
I learned a lot about different fields in Cognitive Science
Learned about pathway for CogSci
This course helps introduce students to a wide range of cognitive science research and faculty and helps students get the ball rolling on setting themselves up for a senior thesis.
Great for general information about cog sci major for juniors.
I thought this course was a good way to start brainstorming about our cognitive science senior thesis projects and a cool way to learn about current research in the cognitive science field.
I learned a lot about the different areas of cognitive science through the guest speakers. I also learned how strong Yale is in this area, all of our faculty were so impressive!
A somewhat better idea of what cognitive science research looks like specifically, but overall not much.

I learned about the different research projects and opportunities happening in different Yale labs currently. I learned about the different aspects of cognitive sciences, and how these these concepts translate into real-life research work.

How to read academic research papers.
How to develop original ideas at a high and in depth level
I gained a lot of insights about the different fields of cognitive psychology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great opportunity to talk to different faculty doing cool things.

Strengths: the broad range of professors that came to talk to us about their research
Weakness: I wasn't really interested in all of the talks (i.e. my focus in cogsci is not computation and economics), but I guess that is inevitable given the nature of the cognitive science major.

Strengths was the ability to hear from professors in the field. Weaknesses was that I was not engaged during the talks that much and not really incentivized to go to class even though they say it is mandatory.
I think this course does not need to be as long as it currently is. I think an 1:15 long course would be enough.
Important information for major.

I think the strengths are it is helpful and inspiring to listen to these speakers. The weaknesses are that I think that it would be more helpful to try and bring in all current people at Yale during research and not people whose labs are shutting down because it is a little misleading because the premise we are told about these guest speakers are that we could work with them on our senior thesis.
the weekly questions felt like busy work as they were never integrated into the weekly speakers presentations.
I think that more discussion in class would be better.

Strengths: Professor Davis was super kind and friendly. We had a wide range of different researchers come in, so I was able to learn about many different types of cognitive sciences research work.
Weakness: The time of the class was later in the afternoon, which wasn't ideal.
Student engagement can be better, half the kids in class were shopping on their laptop.

Strength: opened my eyes to different fields of cognitive psychology and introduced me to different professors; prepared me well for the senior thesis; low work load

Weakness: N/A

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes- required for Cog Sci students but interesting regardless of major
Sure! But only if you're a cog-sci major.
Yes you have to take it if you are a cogsci major. If you are not but interested in learning about current research in the field, then I think it is also interesting to take. It is a half credit.
Yes. I am very thankful the cognitive science department has this course for juniors.
i would!! very easy breezy fun
yes - for cog sci majors.
you can only take this if you are a Cogsci major - so I can't really say I recommend it because you have to take it.
I would recommend it for cognitive science students but if you are not a cog sci major I wouldn't take it
Yes -- it's also required for the cognitive science major, and rightly so.

This course should not be mandatory. Students don't want to be there (so most of them don't show up), which makes the professor also not want to be there because no one is paying attention. The weekly assignments feel entirely like busy work. Especially for students who know what they want to do for their senior thesis, this class is a waste of time.
Yes, for CGSC majors
Yes, because it is mandatory for cognitive science students. The class is also very helpful in preparing students for the senior thesis.
Yes, it's very helpful for cognitive science majors. I felt like I gained valuable information about the thesis process.
